indicator.name: Death Rate in Low-Mortality Diagnosis Related Groups (DRGs)
indicator.description: In-hospital deaths per 1,000 discharges for hospitalizations with low expected mortality (less than 0.5%) among patients ages 18 years and older. Excludes hospital discharges with trauma; cancer; an immunocompromised state; and transfers to an acute care facility

numerator.definition: Number of deaths among cases meeting the inclusion and exclusion rules for the denominator
requirements: Must meet denominator inclusion criteria
Must NOT meet any denominator exclusion criteria
Must have discharge disposition = 20 (death)

denominator.definition: Discharges among patients ages 18 years and older with a low-mortality (less than 0.5% mortality) Medicare Severity Diagnosis Related Group (MS-DRG) code

inclusion_criteria.description: patients ages 18 years and older
low-mortality DRG with less than 0.5% expected mortality rate

exclusion_criteria.description: Conditions that significantly increase mortality risk or represent expected mortality

rules.description: Trauma diagnoses
rules.rationale: Trauma cases have inherently higher mortality risk that may not be preventable

rules.description: Cancer diagnoses
rules.rationale: Cancer patients have expected higher mortality due to underlying malignancy

rules.description: Immunocompromised state diagnoses
rules.rationale: Immunocompromised patients have increased infection and mortality risk

rules.description: Immunocompromised state procedures
rules.rationale: Procedures indicating immunocompromised state increase mortality risk

exclusion_criteria.description: Patients transferred to other acute care facilities

rules.description: Transfer to acute care facility
rules.rationale: Transferred patients' outcomes are not attributable to the discharging hospital

rules.description: Newborns and neonates
rules.rationale: Neonatal mortality has different risk factors and is measured separately

rules.description: Ungroupable DRG
Missing required fields
Missing MDC when user indicates MDC is provided

risk_adjustment.description: No risk adjustment applied - mortality in low-mortality DRGs is considered unexpected
risk_adjustment.rationale: Low-mortality DRGs are selected specifically because they have expected mortality rates below 0.5%, making any death potentially preventable

LOWMODR*.description: MS-DRG codes with low mortality rates (less than 0.5% expected mortality)
examples: Low-risk medical and surgical DRGs
Routine procedures with minimal complications
Common medical conditions with typically good outcomes

TRAUMID.description: ICD-10-CM diagnosis codes for trauma conditions
examples: S00-T88 - Injury, poisoning and certain other consequences of external causes
Specific trauma-related diagnosis codes across body systems

CANCEID.description: ICD-10-CM diagnosis codes for cancer conditions
examples: C00-C97 - Malignant neoplasms
D00-D09 - In situ neoplasms
Related cancer treatment complications

IMMUNID.description: ICD-10-CM diagnosis codes for immunocompromised states
examples: HIV/AIDS conditions
Immunodeficiency disorders
Chemotherapy-induced immunosuppression
Organ transplant status

IMMUNIP.description: ICD-10-PCS procedure codes indicating immunocompromised state
examples: Chemotherapy procedures
Immunosuppressive treatments
Transplant-related procedures

appendix_references.Appendix G: TRAUMID: ICD-10-CM diagnosis codes for trauma conditions
appendix_references.Appendix H: CANCEID: ICD-10-CM diagnosis codes for cancer conditions
appendix_references.Appendix I: IMMUNID: ICD-10-CM diagnosis codes for immunocompromised state
appendix_references.Appendix I: IMMUNIP: ICD-10-PCS procedure codes for immunocompromised state
appendix_references.Appendix O: MDC15PRINDX: Principal diagnosis codes for MDC 15 (Newborns & Neonates)

steps.description: Select discharges for patients aged 18 years and older
Include only discharges with low-mortality MS-DRG codes (<0.5% mortality)
Remove trauma, cancer, and immunocompromised cases
Remove transfers to acute care facilities
Remove newborn/neonatal records
Remove cases with missing data or ungroupable DRG
Find eligible cases with discharge disposition = 20 (death)
Calculate rate: (numerator/denominator) × 1000

examples: Routine procedures
Minor medical conditions
Diagnostic procedures
Common surgical procedures
Stable medical conditions
Rehabilitation cases

key_clinical_notes: Low-mortality DRGs are selected based on expected mortality rates below 0.5%
Any death in these DRGs is considered potentially preventable
Excludes patients with conditions known to increase mortality risk
No risk adjustment since baseline mortality is already very low
Focuses on adult population to avoid neonatal-specific mortality factors
Transfer exclusions prevent attribution of outcomes to inappropriate hospitals
Does not distinguish between causes of death or circumstances

validation_scenarios.description: Adult patient dies during routine gallbladder surgery
Cancer patient dies in low-mortality DRG
Trauma patient dies in low-mortality DRG
HIV patient dies in low-mortality DRG
Patient transferred to another hospital
16-year-old patient dies in low-mortality DRG
Newborn with MDC 15 principal diagnosis
Adult patient dies in high-mortality DRG
key_features: excluded due to DRG mortality rate

validation_scenarios.description: Adult patient discharged home after routine surgery
Patient with chemotherapy procedure dies

indicator.name: Pressure Ulcer Rate
indicator.description: Stage 3 or 4 (or unstageable) pressure ulcers (secondary diagnosis not present on admission) per 1,000 hospital discharges of surgical or medical patients ages 18 years and older. Excludes discharges with length-of-stay less than 3 days; with a principal diagnosis of stage 3 or 4 (or unstageable) pressure ulcer or deep tissue injury at the same anatomic site; with severe burns; or with exfoliative skin disorders; and obstetric discharges

numerator.definition: Discharges with any secondary ICD-10-CM diagnosis code not present on admission for stage 3 or 4 (or unstageable) pressure ulcer, in the absence of a secondary ICD-10-CM diagnosis code present on admission for deep tissue injury or unstageable pressure injury at the same anatomic site

criteria.name: pressure_ulcer_stage_3_4_unstageable
criteria.description: anatomic site-specific pressure ulcer stage 3 or 4 (or unstageable)

criteria.name: deep_tissue_injury_same_site
criteria.description: deep tissue injury or unstageable pressure injury at same anatomic site

requirements: Must meet denominator inclusion criteria
Must NOT meet any denominator exclusion criteria
Must have stage 3/4/unstageable pressure ulcer NOT present on admission
Must NOT have deep tissue injury present on admission at same anatomic site
Unspecified site pressure ulcers automatically qualify (no site matching required)

denominator.definition: Surgical or medical discharges for patients ages 18 years and older

inclusion_criteria.description: patients ages 18 years and older

inclusion_criteria.code_reference: Appendix E: SURGI2R OR Appendix C: MEDIC2R
inclusion_criteria.description: surgical or medical DRG classifications

exclusion_criteria.description: Patients with insufficient stay duration for pressure ulcer development

rules.description: Length of stay less than 3 days
rules.rationale: Insufficient time for hospital-acquired pressure ulcer development

exclusion_criteria.description: Conditions that complicate pressure ulcer assessment or represent pre-existing conditions

rules.description: Principal diagnosis of pressure ulcer stage 3/4/unstageable or deep tissue injury at same anatomic site
rules.rationale: Pre-existing pressure ulcer at same site makes hospital-acquired determination impossible

rules.description: Severe burns (≥20% body surface area)
rules.rationale: Burn patients have different skin integrity issues and wound care requirements

rules.description: Exfoliative skin disorders (≥20% body surface area)
rules.rationale: Exfoliative disorders create skin breakdown unrelated to pressure

rules.description: Obstetric discharges
rules.rationale: Obstetric patients have different risk factors and shorter stays

rules.description: Newborn and neonatal discharges
rules.rationale: Neonatal pressure ulcer risk factors differ significantly from adults

rules.description: Deep tissue injury or unstageable pressure ulcer present on admission at ALL anatomic sites
rules.rationale: Technical exclusion for edge cases (rarely occurs in practice)
rules.note: This scenario does not exist in data tested so far

rules.description: Ungroupable DRG
Missing required fields
Missing MDC when user indicates MDC is provided

risk_adjustment.description: No risk adjustment applied - pressure ulcers are considered preventable with proper care
risk_adjustment.rationale: Pressure ulcers are largely preventable through appropriate positioning, nutrition, and skin care protocols

PI~D*.description: Anatomic site-specific pressure ulcer stage 3 or 4 (or unstageable) diagnosis codes

PINELBOWD*|PINBACKD*|PINHIPD*|PINBUTTD*|.description: Unspecified anatomic site pressure ulcer stage 3 or 4 (or unstageable) diagnosis codes
PINELBOWD*|PINBACKD*|PINHIPD*|PINBUTTD*|.note: Automatically qualify for numerator because anatomic site matching does not apply

DTI~EXD*.description: Anatomic site-specific deep tissue injury diagnosis codes

PI~EXD*.description: Anatomic site-specific pressure ulcer stage 3/4/unstageable or deep tissue injury diagnosis codes (for denominator exclusion)

BURNDX*.description: ICD-10-CM diagnosis codes for severe burns (≥20% body surface area)
examples: T31.20-T31.99 - Burns involving 20% or more of body surface
T32.20-T32.99 - Corrosions involving 20% or more of body surface

EXFOLIATXD*.description: ICD-10-CM diagnosis codes for exfoliative skin disorders (≥20% body surface area)
examples: L26 - Exfoliative dermatitis
L51.1 - Stevens-Johnson syndrome
L51.2 - Toxic epidermal necrolysis

appendix_references.Appendix O: MDC15PRINDX: Principal diagnosis codes for MDC 15 (Newborns & Neonates)

steps.description: Select discharges for patients aged 18 years and older
Include only surgical or medical DRG classifications
Exclude stays less than 3 days
Remove cases with principal pressure ulcer, burns, or exfoliative disorders
Remove obstetric and neonatal records
Remove cases with missing data or ungroupable DRG
Find stage 3/4/unstageable pressure ulcers not present on admission
Exclude cases with deep tissue injury POA at same anatomic site
Include unspecified site pressure ulcers (no site matching required)
Calculate rate: (numerator/denominator) × 1000

key_clinical_notes: Pressure ulcers are largely preventable through proper positioning and skin care
Requires minimum 3-day stay for hospital-acquired pressure ulcer development
Anatomic site matching prevents double-counting when deep tissue injury progresses
Present on admission (POA) indicators are critical for determining hospital-acquired cases
Unspecified site pressure ulcers automatically qualify due to inability to match anatomic sites
Burns and exfoliative disorders excluded due to different wound etiology
Stage 3/4 and unstageable pressure ulcers represent serious preventable complications

validation_scenarios.description: Adult medical patient develops stage 4 sacral pressure ulcer during 7-day stay
key_features: stage 4 sacral pressure ulcer NOT POA
no deep tissue injury POA at sacral site

validation_scenarios.description: Patient admitted with existing stage 3 heel pressure ulcer
key_features: excluded from numerator due to POA

validation_scenarios.description: Patient with deep tissue injury POA develops stage 4 ulcer same site
key_features: deep tissue injury POA at same anatomic site
excluded from numerator due to DTI POA same site

validation_scenarios.description: Patient with 2-day stay develops pressure ulcer
Burn patient with stage 4 pressure ulcer
Obstetric patient develops pressure ulcer
16-year-old develops pressure ulcer
Patient develops unspecified site stage 3 pressure ulcer
key_features: unspecified site stage 3 pressure ulcer NOT POA

validation_scenarios.description: Patient admitted primarily for pressure ulcer treatment
key_features: principal diagnosis: stage 4 sacral pressure ulcer

validation_scenarios.description: Patient with heel DTI POA develops sacral pressure ulcer
key_features: deep tissue injury POA at heel
stage 4 sacral pressure ulcer NOT POA

validation_scenarios.description: Patient with Stevens-Johnson syndrome develops pressure ulcer
Patient develops pressure ulcers at multiple sites
key_features: stage 3 sacral pressure ulcer NOT POA
stage 4 heel pressure ulcer NOT POA

indicator.name: Death Rate among Surgical Inpatients with Serious Treatable Complications
indicator.description: In-hospital deaths per 1,000 surgical discharges among patients ages 18 through 89 years or obstetric patients of any age with serious treatable complications (shock/cardiac arrest, sepsis, pneumonia, gastrointestinal hemorrhage/acute ulcer, or deep vein thrombosis/pulmonary embolism). Measure can be stratified to report deaths by hospitalizations with each type of complication

numerator.definition: Number of deaths among discharges meeting the inclusion and exclusion rules for the denominator
requirements: Must meet denominator inclusion criteria for at least one stratum
Must NOT meet any denominator exclusion criteria for the assigned stratum
Must have discharge disposition = 20 (death)
Assigned to highest-priority stratum when multiple complications present

denominator.definition: Surgical discharges for patients ages 18 through 89 years or obstetric patients of any age with serious treatable complications, having operating room procedures with appropriate timing

inclusion_criteria.description: patients ages 18 through 89 years OR obstetric patients of any age
surgical DRG classifications
operating room procedures with timing requirements
elective admission OR operating room procedure within 2 days of admission
conditions: OR earliest OR procedure ≤ 2 days from admission

inclusion_criteria.description: serious treatable complication in one of five strata
shock or cardiac arrest diagnosis
shock or cardiac arrest resuscitation procedures
inclusion_criteria.timing: same day as or after first OR procedure

inclusion_criteria.description: sepsis diagnosis

STRATUM_PNEUMONIA.name: Pneumonia

inclusion_criteria.description: pneumonia diagnosis

exclusion_criteria: Any diagnosis of viral pneumonia or influenza

STRATUM_GI_HEMORRHAGE.name: Gastrointestinal Hemorrhage/Acute Ulcer

inclusion_criteria.description: gastrointestinal hemorrhage or acute ulcer diagnosis

exclusion_criteria: Principal diagnosis of GI hemorrhage/acute ulcer

STRATUM_DVT_PE.name: Deep Vein Thrombosis/Pulmonary Embolism

inclusion_criteria.description: deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism diagnosis

exclusion_criteria: Principal diagnosis of abortion-related or postpartum obstetric PE

exclusion_criteria.description: Exclusions that apply to all strata

rules.description: Transfer to acute care facility
rules.rationale: Transferred patients' outcomes not attributable to discharging hospital

rules.description: Admission from hospice facility
rules.rationale: Hospice patients have expected higher mortality

rules.description: Newborn and neonatal discharges
rules.rationale: Different population with separate quality measures

exclusion_criteria.description: Exclusions specific to each complication stratum

STRATUM_SHOCK: Esophageal varices with bleeding + qualifying diagnosis (FTR6GV* + FTR6QD*)
STRATUM_PNEUMONIA: Any diagnosis of viral pneumonia or influenza (FTR3EXB*)
STRATUM_GI_HEMORRHAGE: Principal diagnosis of GI hemorrhage/acute ulcer (FTR6DX*)
Esophageal varices with bleeding + qualifying diagnosis (FTR6GV* + FTR6QD*)
STRATUM_DVT_PE: Principal diagnosis of abortion-related or postpartum obstetric PE (OBEMBOL*)

rules.description: Ungroupable DRG
Missing required fields
Missing MDC when user indicates MDC is provided

risk_adjustment.description: No risk adjustment applied - deaths from treatable complications are considered preventable
risk_adjustment.rationale: Serious treatable complications should be manageable with appropriate care, making deaths potentially preventable

examples: Surgical DRGs across multiple body systems
Excludes medical and obstetric DRGs unless specifically included

ORPROC.description: ICD-10-PCS codes for operating room procedures
examples: Major surgical procedures requiring operating room
Excludes minor procedures and bedside interventions

FTR5DX*.description: ICD-10-CM diagnosis codes for shock or cardiac arrest
examples: R57.0 - Cardiogenic shock
R57.1 - Hypovolemic shock
I46.9 - Cardiac arrest, unspecified
R65.21 - Severe sepsis with septic shock

FTR5PR*.description: ICD-10-PCS procedure codes for shock or cardiac arrest resuscitation
examples: 5A12012 - Performance of cardiac output, single, manual
5A2204Z - Restoration of cardiac rhythm, single
A41.9 - Sepsis, unspecified organism
R65.20 - Severe sepsis without septic shock
R65.21 - Severe sepsis with septic shock
J44.0 - COPD with acute lower respiratory infection
J15.9 - Unspecified bacterial pneumonia
J18.9 - Pneumonia, unspecified organism

FTR6DX*.description: ICD-10-CM diagnosis codes for gastrointestinal hemorrhage or acute ulcer
examples: K92.2 - Gastrointestinal hemorrhage, unspecified
K25.0 - Acute gastric ulcer with hemorrhage
K27.0 - Acute peptic ulcer with hemorrhage

FTR2DXB*.description: ICD-10-CM diagnosis codes for deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism
examples: I26.99 - Other pulmonary embolism without acute cor pulmonale
I82.40 - Acute embolism and thrombosis of unspecified deep veins of lower extremity
I82.890 - Acute embolism and thrombosis of other specified veins

appendix_references.Appendix A: ORPROC: ICD-10-PCS codes for operating room procedures
appendix_references.Appendix O: MDC15PRINDX: Principal diagnosis codes for MDC 15 (Newborns & Neonates)
appendix_references.Appendix G: TRAUMID: ICD-10-CM diagnosis codes for trauma conditions
appendix_references.Appendix F: INFECID: ICD-10-CM diagnosis codes for infection conditions

steps.description: Select surgical discharges (ages 18-89 OR obstetric any age)
Confirm presence of OR procedures with appropriate timing
Verify elective admission OR OR procedure within 2 days
Find serious treatable complications in each stratum
Apply exclusions specific to each complication type
Assign cases to single highest-priority stratum when multiple complications present
Remove transfers, hospice admissions, and data quality issues
Find eligible cases with discharge disposition = 20 (death)
Calculate rates: (numerator/denominator) × 1000 for overall and each stratum

life_threatening.description: Complications with highest mortality risk requiring immediate intervention
examples: Cardiogenic shock
Cardiac arrest
Septic shock

severe_systemic.description: Serious systemic complications with high mortality risk
examples: Severe sepsis
Septic shock
Multi-organ dysfunction
Hospital-acquired pneumonia
Upper GI bleeding
Peptic ulcer hemorrhage
Pulmonary embolism
Deep vein thrombosis
Postoperative thrombosis

key_clinical_notes: Focuses on failure to rescue - deaths from treatable complications rather than complications themselves
Strata prioritization ensures each case counted only once in highest-risk category
Procedure timing requirements distinguish planned from emergency surgery
Secondary diagnosis requirement ensures complications developed during hospitalization
Stratum-specific exclusions prevent inclusion of cases where complication was reason for admission
Age range 18-89 excludes very elderly patients with different mortality expectations
Obstetric patients included at any age due to different risk profile during pregnancy/delivery

validation_scenarios.description: Surgical patient develops cardiogenic shock and dies
key_features: secondary diagnosis of shock NOT POA

validation_scenarios.description: Patient develops both sepsis and pneumonia, dies
key_features: meets criteria for both sepsis and pneumonia strata

validation_scenarios.description: Patient admitted primarily for sepsis treatment
key_features: may qualify for other strata if present

validation_scenarios.description: Patient admitted from hospice develops pneumonia and dies
Emergency surgery patient with OR procedure after 2 days
Patient with DVT/PE transferred to another hospital
95-year-old surgical patient develops sepsis and dies
42-year-old obstetric patient develops DVT/PE and dies
Respiratory MDC patient develops pneumonia and dies
Surgical patient develops pneumonia but survives
Patient with esophageal varices and qualifying diagnosis develops GI bleeding
Patient undergoes cardiac resuscitation after surgery and dies

indicator.name: Retained Surgical Item or Unretrieved Device Fragment Count
indicator.description: Number of hospital discharges with a retained surgical item or unretrieved device fragment (secondary diagnosis) among surgical and medical hospitalizations for patients ages 18 years and older or obstetric hospitalizations for patients of any age

calculation.note: This is a COUNT indicator, not a rate

numerator.definition: Discharges with secondary diagnosis of retained surgical item or unretrieved device fragment

criteria.description: retained surgical item or unretrieved device fragment

requirements: Must meet population inclusion criteria
Must NOT meet any exclusion criteria
Must NOT be present on admission

population_inclusion.definition: Surgical or medical discharges meeting age criteria OR obstetric discharges of any age

rules.description: Pregnancy, Childbirth & the Puerperium
Principal diagnosis of retained surgical item or unretrieved device fragment
Secondary diagnosis of retained surgical item or unretrieved device fragment present on admission
Newborns & Other Neonates with Conditions Originating in Perinatal Period
Ungroupable DRG

steps.description: Select all surgical/medical discharges for patients ≥18 years OR obstetric discharges of any age
Remove discharges meeting any exclusion criteria
From remaining population, count cases with secondary diagnosis of retained surgical item/unretrieved device fragment (not POA)
Return total count of qualifying cases

key_differences_from_rate_indicators: This is a COUNT indicator, not a rate per 1,000 discharges
Includes obstetric cases of any age
Focus is on absolute number of preventable events

numerator.definition: Discharges with secondary ICD-10-CM diagnosis code for iatrogenic pneumothorax
requirements: Must meet denominator inclusion criteria
Must NOT meet any denominator exclusion criteria

denominator.definition: Surgical or medical discharges for patients ages 18 years and older

rules.description: Principal diagnosis of non-traumatic pneumothorax
Secondary diagnosis of non-traumatic pneumothorax present on admission
Any diagnosis of specified chest trauma (rib fractures, traumatic pneumothorax, related chest wall injuries)
Any diagnosis of pleural effusion
Thoracic surgery, including lung or pleural biopsy and diaphragmatic repair
Potentially trans-pleural cardiac procedure

CARDSIP*.description: ICD-10-PCS codes for trans-pleural cardiac procedures

steps.description: Select all surgical and medical discharges for patients ≥18 years
Remove discharges meeting any exclusion criteria
From remaining population, identify cases with secondary diagnosis of iatrogenic pneumothorax

indicator.name: Central Venous Catheter-Related Bloodstream Infection Rate
indicator.description: Hospital discharges with central venous catheter-related bloodstream infections (secondary diagnosis) per 1,000 medical and surgical discharges among hospital discharges of patients ages 18 years and older or obstetric discharges for patients of any age

numerator.definition: Discharges with secondary ICD-10-CM diagnosis code for central venous catheter-related bloodstream infections
requirements: Must meet denominator inclusion criteria
Must NOT meet any denominator exclusion criteria
Must NOT be present on admission

denominator.definition: Surgical or medical discharges for patients ages 18 years and older OR obstetric discharges for patients of any age

rules.description: Pregnancy, Childbirth & the Puerperium
Principal diagnosis of central venous catheter-related bloodstream infection
Secondary diagnosis of central venous catheter-related bloodstream infection present on admission
Length of stay less than 2 days
Any diagnosis of cancer
Any diagnosis of immunocompromised state
Any procedure for immunocompromised state
Newborns & Other Neonates with Conditions Originating in Perinatal Period
Ungroupable DRG
Missing required fields
Missing MDC when user indicates MDC is provided

IDTMC3D*.description: ICD-10-CM codes for central venous catheter-related bloodstream infections

IMMUNID*.description: ICD-10-CM codes for immunocompromised state diagnoses

IMMUNIP*.description: ICD-10-PCS codes for immunocompromised state procedures

appendix_references.Appendix I: IMMUNIP: ICD-10-PCS codes for immunocompromised state procedures

steps.description: Select all surgical/medical discharges for patients ≥18 years OR obstetric discharges of any age
Remove discharges meeting any exclusion criteria (POA infections, <2 days LOS, cancer, immunocompromised, neonatal, data quality)
From remaining population, identify cases with secondary diagnosis of central venous catheter-related bloodstream infection (not POA)
Calculate (numerator/denominator) × 1000

key_clinical_notes: Central venous catheters are high-risk devices requiring sterile insertion and maintenance
Bloodstream infections are serious complications that can lead to sepsis and death
Length of stay ≥2 days ensures adequate exposure time for infection development
Cancer and immunocompromised patients excluded due to increased baseline infection risk
This indicator focuses on preventable healthcare-associated infections

indicator.name: In-Hospital Fall-Associated Fracture Rate
indicator.description: In-hospital fall-associated fractures (secondary diagnosis) per 1,000 discharges for patients ages 18 years and older

components.other_fracture: Non-hip fractures only (if no hip fracture)

hierarchy_logic.description: Components are mutually exclusive, hip fractures take priority
rules: If patient has both hip fracture AND other fracture → assign to HIP component only
If patient has other fracture(s) but NO hip fracture → assign to OTHER component
If patient has only hip fracture → assign to HIP component

overall.definition: Discharges with any secondary ICD-10-CM diagnosis code for fracture

hip_fracture_component.definition: Discharges with any secondary ICD-10-CM diagnosis code for hip fracture

other_fracture_component.definition: Discharges with any secondary fracture but WITHOUT any hip fracture

requirements: Must meet denominator inclusion criteria
Must NOT meet any denominator exclusion criteria
Must NOT be present on admission

denominator.definition: Surgical or medical discharges for patients ages 18 years and older

rules.description: Principal diagnosis of fracture
Secondary diagnosis of fracture present on admission
Any diagnosis of joint prosthesis-associated fracture
Pregnancy, Childbirth & the Puerperium
Newborns & Other Neonates with Conditions Originating in Perinatal Period
Ungroupable DRG
Missing required fields
Missing MDC when user indicates MDC is provided

HIPFXID*.note: Subset of FXID codes, takes priority in hierarchy

PROSFXID*.description: ICD-10-CM codes for joint prosthesis-associated fracture
PROSFXID*.note: Excluded because related to device, not fall

steps.description: Select all surgical/medical discharges for patients ≥18 years
Remove discharges meeting any exclusion criteria (POA fractures, prosthetic fractures, obstetric, neonatal, data quality)
From remaining population, identify cases with secondary diagnosis of fracture (not POA)
Classify fractures: Hip (priority) vs Other (non-hip only)
Calculate rates for Overall, Hip, and Other components

key_clinical_notes: Falls are leading cause of injury in hospitalized patients
Hip fractures are most serious fall-related injuries with high morbidity/mortality
Fractures present on admission excluded - focus on hospital-acquired injuries
Prosthetic fractures excluded - different risk profile than fall-related fractures
Hierarchical reporting allows targeted prevention strategies by fracture type

indicator.name: Postoperative Hemorrhage or Hematoma Rate

numerator.definition: Discharges with postoperative hemorrhage/hematoma AND treatment procedure
requirements: Must meet denominator inclusion criteria
Must NOT meet any denominator exclusion criteria
Must have BOTH diagnosis AND treatment procedure
Diagnosis must NOT be present on admission

denominator.definition: Surgical discharges for patients ages 18 years and older with operating room procedures

inclusion_criteria.description: must have at least one operating room procedure

rules.description: Principal diagnosis of postoperative hemorrhage or hematoma
Secondary diagnosis of postoperative hemorrhage or hematoma present on admission
Only operating room procedure is for treatment of hemorrhage/hematoma
Treatment of hemorrhage/hematoma occurs before first operating room procedure
Any diagnosis of coagulation disorder
Principal diagnosis of medication-related coagulopathy
Secondary diagnosis of medication-related coagulopathy present on admission
Thrombolytic medication before or same day as first hemorrhage treatment
Pregnancy, Childbirth & the Puerperium
Newborns & Other Neonates with Conditions Originating in Perinatal Period
Ungroupable DRG

HEMOTH2P*.description: ICD-10-PCS codes for treatment of hemorrhage or hematoma

ORPROC*.description: ICD-10-PCS codes for operating room procedures

THROMBOLYTICP*.description: ICD-10-PCS codes for thrombolytic medication administration

appendix_references.Appendix A: ORPROC: ICD-10-PCS codes for operating room procedures

steps.description: Select surgical discharges for patients ≥18 years with operating room procedures
Remove cases with POA hemorrhage/hematoma, coagulation disorders, medication-related bleeding
Remove cases where hemorrhage treatment is only OR procedure or occurs before primary surgery
Remove cases with thrombolytic therapy before/same day as hemorrhage treatment
Remove obstetric, neonatal, and data quality exclusions
Find cases with postoperative hemorrhage/hematoma AND treatment procedure
Calculate (numerator/denominator) × 1000

timing_rules.description: Treatment must occur after primary operation
Thrombolytics before/same day as treatment excludes case
Must have other OR procedures besides hemorrhage treatment

fallback_logic.description: If procedure dates unavailable, use sequence/timing indicators
fallback_logic.conservative_approach: Include case if timing cannot be determined

key_clinical_notes: Postoperative bleeding is serious complication requiring return to OR
Excludes patients with known bleeding disorders (not preventable)
Requires both diagnosis AND treatment procedure for numerator
Complex timing logic ensures proper sequence of events
Focus on preventable surgical complications

steps.description: Select elective surgical discharges for patients ≥18 years
Remove cases with POA acute kidney failure
Remove cases with dialysis/access procedures before/same day as first OR procedure
Remove cases with cardiac arrest, dysrhythmia, or shock (POA)
Remove cases with CKD stage 5/ESRD, urinary obstruction, solitary kidney with nephrectomy
Remove obstetric, neonatal, and data quality exclusions
Find cases with postoperative acute kidney failure AND dialysis procedure
Calculate (numerator/denominator) × 1000

timing_rules.description: Dialysis must occur after primary operation
Dialysis access must occur after primary operation

fallback_logic.description: If procedure dates unavailable, use sequence/timing indicators
fallback_logic.conservative_approach: Include case if timing cannot be determined

key_clinical_notes: Acute kidney injury requiring dialysis is serious postoperative complication
Excludes patients with pre-existing kidney disease (CKD 5/ESRD)
Excludes high-risk cardiac conditions that predispose to kidney injury
Solitary kidney with nephrectomy exclusion protects expected kidney failure cases
Requires both diagnosis AND dialysis procedure for numerator
Focus on preventable postoperative kidney injury in low-risk patients

criteria.timing_requirement: one or more days after first major OR procedure

Must NOT meet any denominator exclusion criteria
Must have at least ONE of the four numerator criteria
Timing criteria only applied if procedure dates are available

steps.description: Select elective surgical discharges (ATYPE=3) for patients ≥18 years with OR procedures
Remove cases with POA respiratory failure
Remove cases with POA tracheostomy or tracheostomy-only procedures
Remove cases with malignant hyperthermia, neuromuscular, or degenerative neurological disorders
Remove high-risk surgeries (head/neck, esophageal, lung cancer, transplant)
Remove respiratory system MDC, obstetric, and neonatal cases
Remove cases with missing data
Find cases meeting ANY of 4 numerator criteria (diagnosis OR timing-based procedures)
Calculate (numerator/denominator) × 1000

timing_rules.description: >96h ventilation on/after first major OR procedure (0+ days)
24-96h ventilation 2+ days after first major OR procedure
Intubation 1+ days after first major OR procedure
Tracheostomy before OR procedure excludes case

fallback_logic.description: If procedure dates unavailable, use sequence/timing indicators
fallback_logic.conservative_approach: Include case if timing cannot be determined for numerator criteria

key_clinical_notes: Postoperative respiratory failure is serious complication requiring intensive care
Multiple numerator criteria capture different severity levels of respiratory failure
Excludes patients with expected respiratory complications (lung surgery, respiratory diseases)
Excludes neurological conditions predisposing to respiratory failure
Complex timing logic ensures complications are truly postoperative
Focus on preventable respiratory complications in low-risk elective surgery patients

Must NOT meet any denominator exclusion criteria

steps.description: Select surgical discharges for patients ≥18 years with OR procedures
Remove cases with POA DVT/PE or heparin-induced thrombocytopenia
Remove cases with vena cava/thrombectomy procedures before/same day as OR, or late OR procedures (>10 days)
Remove cases with acute brain/spinal injury (POA) or ECMO procedures
Remove obstetric and neonatal cases
Remove cases with missing data
Find cases with perioperative DVT OR PE (secondary, not POA)
Calculate (numerator/denominator) × 1000

timing_rules.description: Vena cava interruption before/same day as OR procedure excludes case
Thrombectomy before/same day as OR procedure excludes case
OR procedure ≥10 days after admission excludes case

fallback_logic.description: If procedure dates unavailable, use sequence/timing indicators
fallback_logic.conservative_approach: Include case if timing cannot be determined

key_clinical_notes: DVT and PE are serious complications of surgery and immobilization
Proximal DVT (thigh/pelvis) has higher risk of embolization than distal DVT
Excludes patients with pre-existing clotting conditions
Late surgery (≥10 days) suggests medical rather than surgical complications
ECMO and acute brain injury predispose to clotting complications
Focus on preventable VTE in perioperative period

steps.description: Select elective surgical discharges (ATYPE=3) for patients ≥18 years with OR procedures
Remove cases with principal sepsis/infection or secondary sepsis/infection present on admission
Remove cases where first OR procedure occurs ≥10 days after admission
Remove obstetric and neonatal cases
Remove cases with missing data or ungroupable DRG
Find cases with postoperative sepsis (secondary, not POA)
Categorize cases by immune function severity for risk adjustment
Calculate (numerator/denominator) × 1000, optionally stratified by risk category

timing_rules.description: OR procedure ≥10 days after admission excludes case

fallback_logic.description: If procedure dates unavailable, use sequence/timing indicators
fallback_logic.conservative_approach: Include case if timing cannot be determined

elective_surgery_requirements.rationale: Emergency surgeries have different risk profiles and care pathways

key_clinical_notes: Postoperative sepsis is a serious complication that can be prevented with proper surgical technique
Elective surgeries allow for better perioperative optimization and standardized protocols
POA status is critical - pre-existing infections are not preventable surgical complications
Late surgery (≥10 days) suggests medical complications rather than surgical site infections
Risk adjustment accounts for patients with compromised immune systems
Focus is on healthcare-associated infections that develop after surgery

validation_scenarios.description: Elective surgery patient develops sepsis 48 hours post-op
Patient with existing infection undergoes surgery
Emergency surgery with postoperative sepsis
key_features: should be excluded regardless of sepsis

validation_scenarios.description: Surgery performed 12 days after admission, then sepsis
key_features: suggests medical rather than surgical complication

steps.description: Select patients ≥18 years with open or non-open abdominopelvic surgery
Remove cases where reclosure occurs before/same day as initial surgery
Remove cases with principal wound disruption or secondary wound disruption POA
Remove cases with LOS < 2 days
Remove obstetric and neonatal cases
Remove cases with missing data or ungroupable DRG
Assign each case to mutually exclusive stratum (open vs non-open approach)
Find cases with both reclosure procedure AND wound disruption diagnosis (not POA)
Calculate overall and stratum-specific rates: (numerator/denominator) × 1000

timing_rules.description: Reclosure before/same day as initial surgery excludes case
Open surgery before reclosure qualifies for open approach stratum
Open surgery on/after reclosure qualifies for non-open approach stratum

fallback_logic.description: If procedure dates unavailable, use sequence/timing indicators
fallback_logic.conservative_approach: Use stratum assignment based on procedure presence

minimum_los_requirements.rationale: Wound dehiscence typically occurs 3-7 days postoperatively

key_clinical_notes: Wound dehiscence is a serious surgical complication that can be prevented with proper technique
Open surgeries have higher baseline dehiscence risk due to larger incisions
Timing is critical - reclosure must occur AFTER initial surgery to be postoperative complication
Dual numerator requirements ensure both procedure and diagnosis are present
Minimum 2-day LOS reflects typical timing of dehiscence occurrence
Stratification allows risk-adjusted comparison between open and minimally invasive approaches

validation_scenarios.description: Open abdominal surgery followed by reclosure for wound dehiscence
Reclosure procedure before initial surgery
Patient with LOS < 2 days
key_features: insufficient time for wound dehiscence to develop

validation_scenarios.description: Wound disruption present on admission
Reclosure procedure without wound disruption diagnosis
Wound disruption diagnosis without reclosure procedure
Patient with both open and non-open procedures assigned to open stratum
key_features: has both open and non-open procedures

steps.description: Select medical or surgical discharges for patients ≥18 years with abdominopelvic procedures
Identify first abdominopelvic procedure date as index for each discharge
Identify accidental puncture/laceration diagnoses by organ system (not POA)
Find evaluation/treatment procedures 1-30 days after index procedure
Match injury diagnoses with related procedures for same organ system
Exclude cases with POA injuries for same organ as related procedure
Exclude cases with missing procedure dates
Remove obstetric and neonatal cases
Remove cases with missing data or ungroupable DRG
Find cases meeting all three numerator criteria (injury + procedure + timing)
Categorize cases by procedure complexity for risk adjustment
Calculate overall and organ-specific rates: (numerator/denominator) × 1000

timing_rules.description: First abdominopelvic procedure establishes index date
Related procedure must be 1-30 days after index procedure

fallback_logic.description: If procedure dates unavailable, exclude from denominator
fallback_logic.conservative_approach: Exclude case if timing cannot be determined

poa_logic_requirements.special_note: POA exclusion only applies when there is a matching related procedure for the same organ system

key_clinical_notes: Accidental organ injury during procedures is a preventable complication
Different organ systems have different injury risks and evaluation procedures
Time window (1-30 days) captures procedures done to evaluate or treat complications
Organ-specific matching ensures clinical relevance of injury-procedure pairs
Both medical and surgical patients can undergo abdominopelvic procedures
Procedure date accuracy is critical for proper time window analysis
Risk adjustment accounts for procedure complexity and inherent injury risk

validation_scenarios.description: Spleen injury during surgery followed by spleen procedure within time window
Spleen injury with GI procedure (different organ systems)
key_features: GI evaluation procedure within time window

validation_scenarios.description: Related procedure outside 1-30 day window
Related procedure on same day as index procedure
POA injury with related procedure for same organ
key_features: related procedure for same organ within window
should be excluded due to POA with matching procedure

validation_scenarios.description: POA injury without related procedure for same organ
key_features: no related procedure for same organ
POA exclusion only applies with matching procedure

validation_scenarios.description: Cannot calculate time windows due to missing dates
Multiple organ injuries with related procedures
key_features: related procedures for both organs within window
should count for both organ systems

validation_scenarios.description: Medical DRG patient with abdominopelvic procedure and injury
Injury as principal diagnosis should exclude
key_features: suggests admission for injury, not procedural complication

steps.description: Select discharges with delivery outcome diagnoses
Require vaginal delivery procedure codes
Require instrument-assisted delivery procedure codes
Remove newborn records (MDC 15 principal diagnosis)
Remove cases with missing data or ungroupable DRG
Find eligible cases with third or fourth degree obstetric trauma
Calculate rate: (numerator/denominator) × 1000

subcategories.IIIa: Less than 50% of external anal sphincter torn
subcategories.IIIb: More than 50% of external anal sphincter torn

third_degree_lacerations.clinical_significance: Affects continence and requires surgical repair

fourth_degree_lacerations.description: Tears extending through anal sphincter and rectal mucosa
fourth_degree_lacerations.clinical_significance: Most severe obstetric trauma, high risk of incontinence

anal_sphincter_tears.description: Isolated anal sphincter tears without third degree laceration

vacuum_extraction.mechanism: Suction cup applied to fetal head

subcategories.mid_forceps: Fetal head engaged but above pelvic floor

key_clinical_notes: Third and fourth degree tears are serious complications affecting continence
Instrument-assisted deliveries have higher trauma risk than spontaneous vaginal deliveries
Forceps generally associated with higher trauma rates than vacuum extraction
Proper technique and case selection can reduce trauma rates
No risk adjustment - all severe tears considered potentially preventable
Includes both episiotomy extensions and spontaneous lacerations
Maternal age, fetal size, and delivery circumstances affect risk

validation_scenarios.description: Instrument-assisted vaginal delivery with third degree laceration
Vacuum-assisted delivery with fourth degree laceration
Cesarean delivery with obstetric trauma (not vaginal)
Spontaneous vaginal delivery without instruments
Newborn record with MDC 15 principal diagnosis
Instrument-assisted delivery without severe trauma
Delivery with multiple obstetric trauma diagnoses
Isolated anal sphincter tear without third degree laceration

indicator.name: Obstetric Trauma Rate – Vaginal Delivery Without Instrument
indicator.description: Hospital discharges with third or fourth degree obstetric injuries per 1,000 vaginal deliveries. Exclude discharges with instrument-assisted delivery

numerator.definition: Discharges with third or fourth degree obstetric injuries among eligible spontaneous vaginal deliveries

criteria.name: obstetric_trauma
criteria.description: third or fourth degree obstetric injury

requirements: Must meet denominator inclusion criteria
Must NOT meet any denominator exclusion criteria
Must have third or fourth degree obstetric injury diagnosis

inclusion_criteria.name: delivery_outcome
inclusion_criteria.description: outcome of delivery diagnosis codes

inclusion_criteria.name: vaginal_delivery
inclusion_criteria.description: vaginal delivery procedure codes

requirements: Must have delivery outcome diagnosis
Must have vaginal delivery procedure
Must NOT have instrument-assisted delivery procedure

exclusion_criteria.description: Exclude instrument-assisted deliveries to focus on spontaneous deliveries

rules.description: Instrument-assisted delivery procedures
rules.rationale: PSI 19 focuses on spontaneous vaginal deliveries; instrument-assisted deliveries covered by PSI 18

rules.description: Newborns & Other Neonates with Conditions Originating in Perinatal Period
rules.rationale: Newborn records, not maternal records

rules.description: Ungroupable DRG
Missing required fields
Missing MDC when user indicates MDC is provided

risk_adjustment.description: No risk adjustment applied - obstetric trauma is considered preventable
risk_adjustment.rationale: Third and fourth degree tears during spontaneous delivery represent preventable complications through proper delivery management

OBTRAID*.description: ICD-10-CM codes for third or fourth degree obstetric injuries
examples: O70.2 - Third degree perineal laceration during delivery
O70.20 - Third degree perineal laceration during delivery, unspecified
O70.21 - Third degree perineal laceration during delivery, IIIa
O70.22 - Third degree perineal laceration during delivery, IIIb
O70.23 - Third degree perineal laceration during delivery, IIIc
O70.3 - Fourth degree perineal laceration during delivery
O70.4 - Anal sphincter tear complicating delivery, not associated with third degree laceration

DELOCMD*.description: ICD-10-CM codes for outcome of delivery
examples: Z37.0 - Single live birth
Z37.1 - Single stillbirth
Z37.2 - Twins, both liveborn
Z37.3 - Twins, one liveborn and one stillborn
Z37.4 - Twins, both stillborn
Z37.50 - Multiple births, unspecified, all liveborn
Z37.51 - Triplets, all liveborn
Z37.52 - Quadruplets, all liveborn
Z37.53 - Quintuplets, all liveborn
Z37.54 - Sextuplets, all liveborn
Z37.59 - Other multiple births, all liveborn
Z37.60 - Multiple births, unspecified, some liveborn
Z37.61 - Triplets, some liveborn
Z37.62 - Quadruplets, some liveborn
Z37.63 - Quintuplets, some liveborn
Z37.64 - Sextuplets, some liveborn
Z37.69 - Other multiple births, some liveborn
Z37.7 - Other multiple births, all stillborn
Z37.9 - Outcome of delivery, unspecified

VAGDELP*.description: ICD-10-PCS codes for vaginal delivery procedures
examples: 10D00Z0 - Extraction of Products of Conception, Low, Open Approach
10D00Z1 - Extraction of Products of Conception, Low Cervical, Open Approach
10D00Z2 - Extraction of Products of Conception, Extraperitoneal, Open Approach
10E0XZZ - Delivery of Products of Conception, External Approach
10D07Z3 - Extraction of Products of Conception, Via Natural or Artificial Opening, Vacuum
10D07Z4 - Extraction of Products of Conception, Via Natural or Artificial Opening, Low Forceps
10D07Z5 - Extraction of Products of Conception, Via Natural or Artificial Opening, Mid Forceps
10D07Z6 - Extraction of Products of Conception, Via Natural or Artificial Opening, High Forceps
10D07Z7 - Extraction of Products of Conception, Via Natural or Artificial Opening, Internal Version
10D07Z8 - Extraction of Products of Conception, Via Natural or Artificial Opening, Other

steps.description: Select discharges with delivery outcome diagnoses
Require vaginal delivery procedure codes
Remove cases with instrument-assisted delivery procedure codes
Remove newborn records (MDC 15 principal diagnosis)
Remove cases with missing data or ungroupable DRG
Find eligible cases with third or fourth degree obstetric trauma
Calculate rate: (numerator/denominator) × 1000

third_degree_lacerations.description: Tears involving the anal sphincter during spontaneous delivery

subcategories.IIIa: Less than 50% of external anal sphincter torn
subcategories.IIIb: More than 50% of external anal sphincter torn

third_degree_lacerations.clinical_significance: Affects continence and requires surgical repair
third_degree_lacerations.spontaneous_delivery_context: More concerning than with instruments as no obvious trauma mechanism

fourth_degree_lacerations.description: Tears extending through anal sphincter and rectal mucosa during spontaneous delivery
fourth_degree_lacerations.clinical_significance: Most severe obstetric trauma, particularly concerning without instrument use
fourth_degree_lacerations.spontaneous_delivery_context: Suggests inadequate perineal support or rapid delivery

anal_sphincter_tears.description: Isolated anal sphincter tears without third degree laceration during spontaneous delivery
anal_sphincter_tears.clinical_significance: Specific type of sphincter injury without obvious trauma cause

spontaneous_vaginal_delivery.description: Natural vaginal delivery without instrument assistance
spontaneous_vaginal_delivery.mechanism: Natural expulsive forces and maternal effort only

controlled_delivery.description: Managed spontaneous delivery with perineal support
controlled_delivery.mechanism: Controlled head delivery and perineal protection

key_clinical_notes: Third and fourth degree tears during spontaneous delivery are concerning as no instrument trauma involved
Lower baseline trauma rates expected compared to instrument-assisted deliveries (PSI 18)
Severe tears without instruments may indicate delivery technique issues or inadequate perineal support
No risk adjustment - all severe tears considered potentially preventable through proper delivery management
Complementary indicator to PSI 18 - compares spontaneous vs. assisted delivery trauma rates
Excludes episiotomy-related extensions unless they extend to third/fourth degree
May reflect precipitous delivery, large fetal size, or suboptimal delivery technique

comparison_with_psi18.expected_rate_relationship: PSI 19 rates typically lower than PSI 18 rates

clinical_interpretation.high_psi19_low_psi18: May indicate issues with spontaneous delivery management
clinical_interpretation.low_psi19_high_psi18: Expected pattern - instruments increase trauma risk

validation_scenarios.description: Spontaneous vaginal delivery with third degree laceration
Spontaneous vaginal delivery with fourth degree laceration
Vaginal delivery with instrument assistance and trauma
Cesarean delivery with obstetric trauma (not vaginal)
Newborn record with MDC 15 principal diagnosis
Spontaneous vaginal delivery without severe trauma
Spontaneous delivery with multiple obstetric trauma diagnoses
Rapid spontaneous delivery with severe laceration
Twin spontaneous delivery with trauma
Isolated anal sphincter tear during spontaneous delivery
